title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: According to the findings, events directly connected to childbearing, such as having a stable partner or not having a partner, living in cohabitation or in marriage, have more influence on decisions about becoming parents than normative expectations, while economic factors (such as having a job) have some impact mainly on postponing childbearing, but do not seem to influence directly whether people will remain childless.
explanation: This statement presents the authors' main finding on factors influencing childlessness.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: Outcomes of our analysis show that women belonging to the older age groups were significantly less likely to belong to the postponer category than younger women, a result which is consistent with previous research findings [Berrington 2004; Heaton et al. 1999; Schoen et al. 1999].
explanation: This statement highlights the relationship between age groups and likelihood of being postponers.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: Women with higher levels (secondary and especially tertiary) of education were much more likely to be postponers than their lower-educated counterparts.
explanation: This claim identifies the impact of education level on the likelihood of postponing parenthood.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: Having paid work indeed significantly increased the chance of postponement for women whose employability in the Hungarian labour market—characterised by very limited parent-friendly flexibility—can be seriously constrained by having children.
explanation: This statement asserts the influence of employment on postponing childbearing among women.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: At the same time (because of the highly gendered nature of family practices that can largely 'free' men from adjusting their work-life balance after having children) employment did not have the same effect on men in the context of having children.
explanation: This claim differentiates the impact of employment on childbearing between men and women.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: Living in a partnership significantly decreased the chances of temporary as well as voluntary childlessness (being a postponer or a childfree articulator) for both genders especially in the case of marriage (but also in the case of cohabitation).
explanation: This statement emphasizes the role of partnership in reducing childlessness.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: Having their own apartment was shown to somewhat decrease the chance of belonging to the childfree articulator categories for both men and women, a result that coincides with previous Hungarian research findings: having one's own apartment is regarded as a necessary precondition of having children.
explanation: This claim links home ownership with lower likelihood of voluntary childlessness.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: According to our results, postponement tends to characterise younger single women with higher education and paid work.
explanation: This statement identifies the demographic profile of those who tend to postpone parenthood.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: Value orientations did not seem to have much influence on our female respondents' timing of parenthood since neither religion, nor traditional family-related attitudes had significant effects (except the importance of children for a happy marriage).
explanation: This claim indicates the limited role of value orientations on women's timing of parenthood.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: For men we also found that age, partnerships status and education are relevant factors that influence the timing of becoming fathers.
explanation: This statement outlines the factors influencing men's decisions to become fathers.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: Only 22% of postponer women and 14% of postponer men had become a parent by 2008, which clearly shows that the majority of postponers were unable to realise their reproductive plans.
explanation: This claim highlights the low realization rate of reproductive plans among postponers.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: The greatest obstacle standing in the way of having children is presumably the lack of a stable partner relationship: this is supported by our finding that the women with the greatest chance of becoming a mother in the examined period were those living in some kind of partner relationship (marriage or cohabitation).
explanation: This statement identifies lack of stable partnership as the main obstacle to having children.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: Partnership is one the most important factors regarding entry into fatherhood.
explanation: This claim emphasizes the critical role of partnership in men's transition to fatherhood.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: A vast portion of Hungarian postponers do not become parents even at a very late reproductive age.
explanation: This statement asserts that most postponers remain childless despite reaching late reproductive age.

title: Who Remains Childless? Unrealised Fertility Plans In Hungary*
claim: The main factors contributing to perpetual postponement are neither economic nor ideational factors, but a lasting life-course 'non-event' of not forming a stable partnership, characterising an increasing number of people.
explanation: This claim concludes that lack of stable partnerships, rather than economic or ideological factors, drives perpetual postponement.

title: Chapter 4
claim: The analysis confirms that female education is the dominant socioeconomic driver of fertility transitions in the developing world.
explanation: This statement presents a novel finding that female education is the main driver, as per the study's analysis.

title: Chapter 4
claim: demonstrating that socio-economic changes alone provide only a partial and often inadequate explanation for fertility trends.
explanation: This reveals that socio-economic factors do not fully account for fertility trends, highlighting the need for additional explanations.

title: Chapter 4
claim: Anomaly 1**: Before the onset of the transition fertility is unresponsive to increases** in education.
explanation: This identifies that fertility rates do not decline with increased education before the transition begins.

title: Chapter 4
claim: Anomaly 2**: The level of education at the onset of transitions (\the threshold\")** varies very widely among countries."
explanation: This shows that the education level required to initiate fertility transitions differs significantly across countries.

title: Chapter 4
claim: Anomaly 3: The pace of change in fertility in mid-transition is faster than expected from the regression line.
explanation: This finds that fertility declines more rapidly during the mid-transition phase than predicted by the model.

title: Chapter 4
claim: Anomaly 4: Once a country in a region has entered the transition, neighboring countries follow sooner than expected from their level of education.
explanation: This demonstrates that fertility transitions spread regionally faster than education levels alone would suggest.

title: Comparative Population Studies Vol. 39, 1 (2014): 49-72 (Date Of Release: 20.02.2014)
claim: The empirical results indicate that the FST is a suitable theoretical basis for a consistent and differentiated explanation of increased childlessness.
explanation: This statement presents a novel finding that validates Frame Selection Theory (FST) as an effective model for explaining increased childlessness.

title: Comparative Population Studies Vol. 39, 1 (2014): 49-72 (Date Of Release: 20.02.2014)
claim: The behavioural relevance of opportunity costs for family formation depends on whether the situation and the frame match - i.e. the compatibility of a family framing - and not simply on the preferences or the values of the individuals.
explanation: This claim introduces the interaction between situational compatibility and opportunity costs as a key factor influencing family formation.

title: Comparative Population Studies Vol. 39, 1 (2014): 49-72 (Date Of Release: 20.02.2014)
claim: The process of sociocultural demonopolisation contributes to couples intending not to start a family so that the question of the 'right' time for family formation does not even arise.
explanation: This statement provides a new perspective on how sociocultural changes influence the decision-making process regarding family formation.

title: Comparative Population Studies Vol. 39, 1 (2014): 49-72 (Date Of Release: 20.02.2014)
claim: A missing desire to have children is based rather on doubting the appropriateness of becoming a parent in the respective private circumstances, a doubt that has increased due to sociocultural changes.
explanation: This claim offers a novel interpretation of the reasons behind declining desires for parenthood, linking it to sociocultural changes rather than personal values.

title: Comparative Population Studies Vol. 39, 1 (2014): 49-72 (Date Of Release: 20.02.2014)
claim: Thus, the FST approach emphasizes: only after breaking the monopoly of the family frame for partnerships, increased opportunity costs can become relevant for mass behaviour, since only after weakening mfam the relation between Ufam and Ualt) becomes relevant.
explanation: This statement integrates Frame Selection Theory with the concept of sociocultural demonopolisation, highlighting the conditional relevance of opportunity costs in family formation.

title: A Turning Point In Italian Fertility
claim: Our findings indicate that the postponement of first order fertility in Italy involved mostly women holding a university degree in younger cohorts.
explanation: This statement presents a novel finding about the demographic characteristics of women who postponed fertility.

title: A Turning Point In Italian Fertility
claim: Moreover, in the early 2000s a recovery process at later ages was just beginning, even if limited in magnitude.
explanation: This sentence introduces a new observation about the onset of fertility recovery in the early 2000s.

title: A Turning Point In Italian Fertility
claim: Finally, significant differences at a regional level were found: specifically, until recently, southern Italy still displayed a limited birth postponement and no recovery.
explanation: This claim highlights regional disparities in fertility postponement and recovery within Italy.

title: A Turning Point In Italian Fertility
claim: The propensity of a woman to remain childless until her 30s increased among younger generations until the cohorts born in the late 1960s.
explanation: This finding reveals a generational trend in delayed childbearing.

title: A Turning Point In Italian Fertility
claim: Women who had worked without interruption had a higher risk of remaining childless during their 20s, compared to women who had never worked.
explanation: This statement identifies a relationship between continuous employment and increased risk of childlessness in early adulthood.

title: A Turning Point In Italian Fertility
claim: Fertility recovery after age 30 is higher among women who stopped working.
explanation: This claim establishes a link between stopping work and higher rates of fertility recovery post-30.

title: A Turning Point In Italian Fertility
claim: Postponement and recovery are strongly linked to the timing of union formation.
explanation: This finding connects fertility behavior with the timing of entering unions.

title: A Turning Point In Italian Fertility
claim: Women with a partner whose education is low have a higher risk of having a first child before age 30 but also a lower propensity to recover if they remain childless after this age.
explanation: This statement uncovers the influence of partner's education on fertility timing and recovery.

title: A Turning Point In Italian Fertility
claim: Residential proximity to parents has a positive impact on entry into motherhood, net of other covariates.
explanation: This claim highlights the role of family proximity in facilitating motherhood

title: A Turning Point In Italian Fertility
claim: The turning point in Italian fertility was strongly linked to the innovative behaviors of more educated women. They were the first to postpone births (and union formation) among Italian women.
explanation: This finding attributes the fertility turning point to the actions of highly educated women.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: The findings indicate that women and men have distinctive pathways into childlessness.
explanation: This is an original claim by the authors demonstrating that gender differences exist in pathways to childlessness.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Educational attainment increases the likelihood of remaining childless among women only.
explanation: The authors' finding that higher education affects women's childlessness but not men's.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: A stable career increases the likelihood of remaining childless among women, but it increases the likelihood of entering fatherhood.
explanation: The authors claim that continuous employment has opposite effects on childlessness for women and men.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Years without a partner is positively associated with childlessness among both women and men.
explanation: The authors found that more years without a partner increases likelihood of childlessness for both genders.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Not having had a partnership and having had multiple partnerships are strong determinants of childlessness, especially among men.
explanation: This claim shows that these factors significantly affect childlessness, more so for men.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Every extra level of educational attainment increases the odds of remaining childless by 14% for women.
explanation: The authors' quantitative finding on the impact of education level on women's childlessness.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Educational attainment does not significantly increase men's odds of remaining childless.
explanation: The authors found that men's education level does not affect their likelihood of remaining childless.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Women with continuous employment have a 1·3 times higher odds of remaining childless.
explanation: The authors provide a quantitative claim about the effect of employment continuity on women's childlessness.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Having been continuously employed reduces men's odds of remaining childless by 36%.
explanation: This quantifies how stable employment decreases men's likelihood of childlessness.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Every extra year without a partner increases women's odds of remaining childless by 15% and men's odds by 17%.
explanation: The authors found that time without a partner increases childlessness for both genders.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Age at first union does not significantly change women's or men's odds of remaining childless.
explanation: The authors claim that timing of entering first partnership does not impact childlessness.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Never having had a partner increases the odds of remaining childless by about 7 times for women and 11·5 times for men.
explanation: Quantifies how not having a partner increases childlessness, especially for men.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Men who have had multiple relationships have significantly higher odds of remaining childless than their female counterparts.
explanation: The authors found that multiple partnerships affect men's childlessness more than women's.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Multiple unions increase both women's and men's odds of remaining childless: women's odds increase by about 1·6 times, whereas men's odds increase by about 2·2 times.
explanation: Quantitative finding on the impact of multiple partnerships on childlessness for both genders.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Women who have no breaks over the course of their employment career are less likely, whereas their male counterparts are more likely to enter parenthood.
explanation: The authors found that continuous employment affects women's and men's parenthood differently.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Remaining without a partner during the fertile years is a major restriction for having children for women. Noteworthy, it appears to be an even larger restriction for men.
explanation: The authors found that being partnerless is a significant determinant of childlessness, more so for men.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Women are somewhat more likely than men to seize second chances to have a child.
explanation: The authors claim that women are more likely than men to have children after previous relationships.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Not all pathways are gendered. For example, the impact of years without a partner is similar for women and men.
explanation: The authors found that some factors affect both genders equally regarding childlessness.

title: Pathways Into Childlessness: Evidence Of Gendered Life Course Dynamics
claim: Men and women who have followed similar life pathways nevertheless have disparate chances of remaining childless.
explanation: The authors found that even with similar life courses, men and women have different childlessness outcomes.

title: Comparative Population Studies - Postponement And Recuperation In Cohort Fertility: Austria, Germany And Switzerland In A European Context
claim: Using three key indicators of the postponement transition - initial fertility level, absolute fertility decline at younger ages, and the relative degree of fertility 'recuperation' at older ages - we demonstrate that each of these components is salient for explaining contemporary cross-country differences in cohort fertility.
explanation: This is a claim because the authors assert that these components explain cross-country differences, contributing new knowledge.

title: Comparative Population Studies - Postponement And Recuperation In Cohort Fertility: Austria, Germany And Switzerland In A European Context
claim: Recuperation is especially important, but is also clearly patterned by birth order: whereas all the countries analysed have experienced a vigorous recovery of delayed first births, pronounced differentials are observed with regard to the recuperation of second and particularly of third and later births.
explanation: This is a claim because the authors present findings on how recuperation varies by birth order, offering new insights.

title: Comparative Population Studies - Postponement And Recuperation In Cohort Fertility: Austria, Germany And Switzerland In A European Context
claim: We propose an extended analysis of cohort postponement and recuperation, based on a set of simple rules, expanded graphical representations and selected summary indicators.
explanation: This is a claim because the authors introduce a novel methodological contribution.

title: Comparative Population Studies - Postponement And Recuperation In Cohort Fertility: Austria, Germany And Switzerland In A European Context
claim: Based on our findings, Austria, Germany and Switzerland share a number of common features in their postponement transition: the low cohort fertility level prior to its onset, its relatively even pace over time, but also the low or almost no recuperation at higher birth orders.
explanation: This is a claim because the authors present new findings about common features in these countries' fertility transitions.

title: Comparative Population Studies - Postponement And Recuperation In Cohort Fertility: Austria, Germany And Switzerland In A European Context
claim: Among the countries analysed, the United States clearly stand out for their persistently high fertility among teenage women and young adults, and therefore a limited extent of birth postponement combined with an 'overcompensation' of the postponed fertility during the recuperation stage.
explanation: This is a claim because the authors assert new findings about the unique fertility pattern in the United States.

title: Comparative Population Studies - Postponement And Recuperation In Cohort Fertility: Austria, Germany And Switzerland In A European Context
claim: Adding education into the analysis explains a considerable part of the postponement process. Rising educational attainment among women has strongly contributed to declining first birth rates at younger ages in the post-1950 cohorts in five out of the nine countries studied in the supplementary online Appendix.
explanation: This is a claim because the authors find that rising education contributes to declining early fertility.

title: Comparative Population Studies - Postponement And Recuperation In Cohort Fertility: Austria, Germany And Switzerland In A European Context
claim: Projection scenarios of completed fertility suggest relatively stable fertility levels in the countries that have progressed furthest in the postponement process, while for the countries where childbearing postponement started relatively late, the scenarios often diverge, capturing considerable uncertainty in the unfolding recuperation.
explanation: This is a claim because the authors present projection findings, contributing new knowledge.

title: Comparative Population Studies - Postponement And Recuperation In Cohort Fertility: Austria, Germany And Switzerland In A European Context
claim: As the projected fertility and childlessness levels differ considerably across countries, the cross-country differences in low fertility observed are here to stay. The completed fertility of the early 1980s cohorts in individual countries is likely to range between the threshold of lowest-low cohort fertility of 1.3 births per woman and the replacement fertility levels of 2.1 births per woman.
explanation: This is a claim because the authors assert that cross-country fertility differences will persist, providing new projections.

title: Comparative Population Studies - Postponement And Recuperation In Cohort Fertility: Austria, Germany And Switzerland In A European Context
claim: We highlight the role of increasing education and the diversity in the trends of fertility recuperation, which has become a critical determinant for fertility trends in Europe, and which has been relatively weak in the three countries analysed.
explanation: This is a claim because the authors emphasize their findings on the role of education and weak recuperation in the countries analyzed.

title: Lgbtq+ Individuals And Pregnancy Outcomes: A Commentary
Parenting Desire Among Sexual Minority Women In China: From The Stigma Perspective
claim: Lesbian women reported lower structural and individual stigma and parenting desire levels than bisexual women.
explanation: This is an original finding indicating differences between lesbian and bisexual women in stigma and parenting desire levels.

title: Parenting Desire Among Sexual Minority Women In China: From The Stigma Perspective
claim: Sexual minority women's high adherence to Confucianism, internalized homophobia, and rejection sensitivity were positively associated with their increased parenting desires.
explanation: This is a novel result showing positive associations between stigma factors and parenting desire among sexual minority women.

title: Parenting Desire Among Sexual Minority Women In China: From The Stigma Perspective
claim: Adherence to Confucianism and discrimination events were associated with parenting desire through internalized homophobia, but not rejection sensitivity.
explanation: This is an original finding demonstrating the mediation effect of internalized homophobia between stigma and parenting desire.

title: Parenting Desire Among Sexual Minority Women In China: From The Stigma Perspective
claim: Outness to one's family buffered the direct link between adherence to Confucianism and parenting desire and strengthened the direct link between discrimination events and internalized homophobia and the indirect link between discrimination events and parenting desire.
explanation: This is a novel finding showing the moderating role of outness to one's family in the relationships studied.

title: Does Having Children Bring Life Satisfaction In Europe?
claim: Having children increases parents' life satisfaction by 0.33–0.41 points on a 10 point scale.
explanation: This statement presents a novel quantitative finding on the positive impact of children on parents' life satisfaction.

title: Does Having Children Bring Life Satisfaction In Europe?
claim: This effect is significantly more pronounced when parents are over the age of 50.
explanation: This claim highlights a specific demographic where the positive impact of children on life satisfaction is greater.

title: Does Having Children Bring Life Satisfaction In Europe?
claim: Children's effects on life satisfaction and happiness is negative for single and full-time working parents.
explanation: This finding identifies a negative relationship between having children and well-being for specific parent groups.

title: Does Having Children Bring Life Satisfaction In Europe?
claim: The positive effect of having children on life satisfaction and happiness has substantially eroded over the EVS waves which explains the reductions in the fertility rate in Europe.
explanation: This claim links the diminishing positive impact of children on well-being over time to declining fertility rates.

title: Narratives Of The Future And Fertility Decision-Making In Uncertain Times. An Application To The Covid-19 Pandemic
claim: Results suggest that, because of COVID-induced uncertainty, subjective perceptions and personal narratives of the future - also shaped by media 'shared narratives' - gained the upper hand over the shadow of the past in influencing fertility intentions.
explanation: This statement is directly taken from the results section, presenting a novel finding about the influence of future-oriented narratives over past experiences on fertility intentions during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Narratives Of The Future And Fertility Decision-Making In Uncertain Times. An Application To The Covid-19 Pandemic
claim: In addition, we provide evidence of a causal impact of shared narratives of the future on fertility intentions through an online experiment simulating a 'real' exposure of the respondents to a new media narrative on the expected length of the emergency.
explanation: This claim explicitly states the novel methodological approach and the establishment of a causal relationship between media narratives and fertility intentions.

title: Narratives Of The Future And Fertility Decision-Making In Uncertain Times. An Application To The Covid-19 Pandemic
claim: Respondents who were exposed to scenarios in which a return to normality would not occur for at least two years significantly reduced their post-treatment fertility intentions.
explanation: This claim is directly derived from the experimental results, highlighting the causal effect of pessimistic media narratives on reducing fertility intentions.

claim: Maternity ideals, and the ideal of the "natural" birth, can be particularly stressful on those who fear childbirth.
explanation: This statement presents a novel finding that links maternity and natural birth ideals to increased stress in individuals with a fear of childbirth.

claim: Norms concerning femininity and cisgender can contribute to FOC among those who do not comfortably conform with feminine body ideals or feminine gender expressions.
explanation: This claim introduces the novel idea that femininity and cisgender norms specifically contribute to fear of childbirth in individuals who do not align with traditional feminine ideals.

claim: The present study shows how bodily dysphoria gained from a feminine-coded body, that conflicts with one's self-image, may be experienced as particularly stressful prior to and during childbirth.
explanation: This statement presents a new connection between bodily dysphoria related to feminine-coded bodies and increased stress levels in the context of childbirth.

claim: Several participants in the present study described how norms concerning femininity and/or cisgender contributed to their FOC. This can be understood as a minority stress affecting those who do not comfortably conform with feminine body ideals or feminine gender expressions, during pregnancy and childbirth.
explanation: This claim introduces the concept of minority stress as a contributing factor to fear of childbirth among individuals who do not conform to traditional feminine norms.

title: Voluntarily childless men: socio-cultural reasons why young Poles are not assuming a parental role.
claim: The analysis of the collected data made it possible to identify three categories/types of voluntarily childless men: 1) those who postpone their decision about parenthood; 2) those who, in a way, fall into the first identified category, namely, they postpone their decision but they are not the ones who ultimately make the decision; they agree not to have any offspring ('if my wife decides to have a child, we will, if not, we will be childless'), they currently have a neutral attitude towards having offspring; 3) those who have made up their mind/ are strongly committed to not having any offspring.
explanation: This statement presents a novel classification of voluntarily childless men based on the analysis of collected data, contributing new understanding to the field.

title: Voluntarily childless men: socio-cultural reasons why young Poles are not assuming a parental role.
claim: Voluntary childlessness can be interpreted in terms of post-modern changes in values, cultural norms, changes in cultural concepts of gender, as well as economic changes and changes in work organisation.
explanation: This statement offers a new interpretation of voluntary childlessness, linking it to various post-modern socio-cultural and economic changes, thereby contributing to the theoretical understanding in the field.

title: Voluntarily childless men: socio-cultural reasons why young Poles are not assuming a parental role.
claim: The trend towards individualisation and the pluralisation of lifestyles is irreversible, also in Polish society.
explanation: This statement posits a new conclusion based on the research data that individualisation and pluralisation of lifestyles in Polish society are irreversible trends, adding to the discourse on societal transformation.

title: Voluntarily childless men: socio-cultural reasons why young Poles are not assuming a parental role.
explanation: This statement enumerates the new factors identified by the study at different social levels that influence voluntary childlessness, contributing to the empirical knowledge in the field.

title: Couples' Decisions To Have A First Child: Comparing Pathways To Early And Late Parenthood
claim: The decision-making among the couples in our study was generally quite implicit.
explanation: The authors directly state their main finding that decision-making was implicit.

title: Couples' Decisions To Have A First Child: Comparing Pathways To Early And Late Parenthood
claim: This is true not only for those couples who had their first child at a relatively young age, but, perhaps more surprisingly, also for many of the older, mainly highly educated, couples.
explanation: Specifies that implicit decision-making applies to both early and late parenthood couples.

title: Couples' Decisions To Have A First Child: Comparing Pathways To Early And Late Parenthood
claim: Older parents more often explicitly assured themselves of their partner's wish for a child early in the relationship than young parents, while young couples agreed implicitly more often on having children.
explanation: Differentiates between older and younger parents' explicit versus implicit decision-making.

title: Couples' Decisions To Have A First Child: Comparing Pathways To Early And Late Parenthood
claim: We emphasize that our study suggests that a first birth is not typically preceded by an extensive and explicit decision-making process as sketched in theories on individualisation and lifestyle choices.
explanation: Highlights that first births may not involve the extensive decision-making processes suggested by existing theories.

title: Couples' Decisions To Have A First Child: Comparing Pathways To Early And Late Parenthood
claim: Costs and rewards are not always deliberately considered.
explanation: Observes that considerations of costs and rewards are not always explicit in the decision-making process.

title: Couples' Decisions To Have A First Child: Comparing Pathways To Early And Late Parenthood
claim: For many people who do have children, the choice to have them might have been self-evident, and the planning of the first child does not have to be experienced as a complex process.
explanation: Suggests that having children can be a self-evident decision without complex planning.

title: Factors That Shape Women'S Reproductive Decision-Making: A Scoping Review
claim: This scoping review is the first to collectively examine WRDM evidence across the span of types of reproductive decisions, addressing a gap in prior research.
explanation: The authors state that their review is the first to comprehensively examine WRDM across various reproductive decisions, highlighting a novel contribution to the field.

title: Factors That Shape Women'S Reproductive Decision-Making: A Scoping Review
claim: The findings highlight WRDM is not only informed by personal desires and intentions, but is also shaped by physical, economic, temporal, relational, socio-cultural, and gendered factors and structures.
explanation: The authors demonstrate that WRDM is influenced by a broad range of interconnected factors beyond individual preferences, providing a comprehensive understanding of the influences on reproductive decisions.

title: Factors That Shape Women'S Reproductive Decision-Making: A Scoping Review
claim: The findings highlight the continuing influence of gendered norms, expectations, inequities, and pronatalist discourses in shaping WRDM.
explanation: The authors reveal through their analysis that societal and cultural gendered factors significantly impact women's reproductive choices, underscoring the persistent role of these norms.

title: Factors That Shape Women'S Reproductive Decision-Making: A Scoping Review
claim: The findings draw attention to the need to conceptualise WRDM beyond an idea of unconstrained choice, but rather, as situated within a range of intersecting physical, economic, temporal, relational, socio-cultural, and gendered influencing factors and constraints.
explanation: The authors propose a new framework for understanding WRDM, emphasizing that reproductive decisions are constrained and influenced by multiple intersecting factors.

title: Factors That Shape Women'S Reproductive Decision-Making: A Scoping Review
claim: These factors and constraints emphasise the need for gender equitable health and social policy, and challenging inequitable gendered norms, to support women to make positive reproductive decisions that support their health, wellbeing, and life ambitions.
explanation: The authors argue that addressing the identified constraints through policy changes and challenging gender norms is essential for supporting women's reproductive autonomy and wellbeing.

title: Factors That Shape Women'S Reproductive Decision-Making: A Scoping Review
claim: The findings also highlight women's reproductive decisions occur over time and are often revisited across the life course.
explanation: The authors identify that WRDM is a dynamic process influenced by changes and developments throughout a woman's life, emphasizing the temporal aspect of reproductive decision-making.

title: Why Childless Men And Women Give Up On Having Children
claim: Women have a much higher chance than men of giving up on having children or switching compared to permanently considering having children.
explanation: The study found a significant gender difference, with women more likely to give up on having children.

title: Why Childless Men And Women Give Up On Having Children
claim: Respondents who were employed were less likely to have given up on having children.
explanation: Employment, indicating financial security, was associated with a lower likelihood of giving up on having children.

title: Why Childless Men And Women Give Up On Having Children
claim: Respondents who reported that their parents wanted them to have children were more likely to belong to the ''permanently considering having children'' group.
explanation: Parental influence was linked to maintaining the consideration of having children.

title: Why Childless Men And Women Give Up On Having Children
claim: Respondents with high emotional autonomy were more likely to be found in the ''permanently considering having children'' group and the ''permanently not considering having children'' group.
explanation: Emotional autonomy influenced whether individuals persisted in considering having children or disengaged from that goal.

title: Why Childless Men And Women Give Up On Having Children
claim: Respondents who anticipate positive consequences of parenthood were less likely to give up on having children.
explanation: Positive attitudes towards parenthood were associated with a lower likelihood of giving up.

title: Why Childless Men And Women Give Up On Having Children
claim: Respondents who anticipate negative consequences of parenthood were more likely to give up on having children.
explanation: Negative attitudes towards parenthood were associated with a higher likelihood of giving up.

title: It Takes Two To Tango: Couples' Happiness And Childbearing
claim: We find that a higher level of happiness of both men and women is associated with a higher risk of having a first child, meaning that happier people are more likely to become parents sooner.
explanation: Demonstrates a positive correlation between both partners' happiness and the likelihood of having a first child.

title: It Takes Two To Tango: Couples' Happiness And Childbearing

title: The Influence Of Income And Work Hours On First Birth For Australian Women
